reasoning: First things first, Netflix sits outside my circle of competence.  I don’t pretend to be an expert in the intricacies of content creation, subscriber churn and streaming algorithms the way I understand consumer staples like Coca-Cola or banks like Bank of America.  Second, its competitive moat feels questionable.  Yes, strong operating margins (avg ~38%) show pricing power today, but a streaming business faces an endless arms race of content spending and ruthless competitors with low switching costs.  Third, management has financed growth by issuing stock and piling on debt (Debt/Equity ~3.0) rather than returning cash to shareholders – not the sort of capital allocation that excites me.  Fourth, while ROE of ~20% is respectable, earnings have been inconsistent (only 4 of 10 periods above 15% ROE) and the balance sheet is levered, with liquidity metrics unclear.  Fifth, the stock trades well above even a conservative intrinsic value estimate of ~$371 per share (15% haircut on a ~$436 DCF value), leaving a negative margin of safety.  Finally, long-term prospects in a cut-throat, capital-intensive industry full of rapid change and fading content exclusivity strike me as riskier than the durable, wide-moat businesses I prefer.  Compared to opportunities in my portfolio – think See’s Candies, Apple and BNSF – Netflix simply fails the first rule: I don’t understand it well enough, and it’s not available at a very attractive price.  I’ll pass.

fundamental_analysis.details: Strong ROE of 19.8%; High debt to equity ratio of 3.0; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 42.8% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 4/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 38.1%) indicate pricing power moat; High performance stability (71.9%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Moderate book value per share growth

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (4.2%, 5y), Stage 2 (2.1%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
